abstract.text: The sound played upon delivery of a notification.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Create a
object when you want the system to play a specific sound when it delivers with your notification. To play the default system sound, create your sound object using the
method. If you want to play a custom sound, create a new sound object and specify the name of the audio file that you want to play.
For local notifications, assign the sound object to the
property of your
object. For a remote notification, assign the name of your sound file to the
key in the
dictionary. You can also use a notification service app extension to add a sound file to a notification shortly before delivery. In your extension, create a
object and add it to your notification content in the same way that you’d for a local notification.

Audio files must already be on the user’s device before the system can play them. If you use a predefined set of sounds for your notifications, include the audio files in your app’s bundle. For all other sounds, the
object looks only in the following locations:
The
directory of the app’s container directory.
The
directory of one of the app’s shared group container directories.
The main bundle of the current executable.
The system sound facility plays custom alert sounds, so they must be in one of the following audio data formats:
Linear PCM
MA4 (IMA/ADPCM)
µLaw
aLaw
You can package the audio data in an
, or
file. Sound files must be less than 30 seconds in length. If the sound file is longer than 30 seconds, the system plays the default sound instead.
You can use the
command-line tool to convert sounds. For example, to convert the system sound
to IMA4 audio in a CAF file, use the following command in Terminal:

abstract.text: Push user-facing notifications to the user’s device from a server, or generate them locally from your app.
The editable content for a notification.
The sound that plays when the system delivers the notification.
An icon associated with an action.
A media file associated with a notification.
The uneditable content of a notification.
A protocol the system uses to provide context relevant to user notifications.
The sound played upon delivery of a notification.
Creates a custom sound object for critical alerts.
Creates a custom sound object for critical alerts with the volume you specify.
Returns an object representing the default sound for notifications.
The default sound used for critical alerts.
Creates a sound object that plays the default critical alert sound at the volume you specify.
Creates a sound object that represents a custom sound file.
A string providing the name of a sound file.
Send notifications to the user’s device with a JSON payload.
Configure and display your app’s communication notifications by using intents.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables encoding and decoding in a manner that is robust against object substitution attacks.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
